Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a gas chromatograph and isotope ratio mass spectrometer interface for compound-specific isotope analyses at the University of North Carolina Wilmington
Award.AbstractNarration:
Isotopic analysis of individual chemical compounds is a technique that is quickly proving to be one of the most groundbreaking advances in biogeochemical research. This award provides funding to early career researchers and tenured faculty at the University of North Carolina Wilmington (UNCW) Center for Marine Science (CMS) to acquire an instrument for compound-specific isotopic analyses. The instrumentation will contribute to the teaching and research missions of both UNCW and CMS. Research projects that will utilize the instrumentation include: reconstructing paleoclimate of the circum-Caribbean and southeastern U.S, sourcing of atmospheric pollution, improving identification and characterization of prehistoric agriculture and land use, understanding polar food webs, reconstructing prehistoric tsunamis, storms, and changes in relative sea level, and investigating geoarchaeology of late Pleistocene deposits in the Paleolithic of Portuguese Estremadura. The PIs will incorporate the new instrumentation into a variety of graduate and undergraduate courses at UNCW. For example, students in the stable isotope geochemistry course will analyze standard mixtures of organic compounds from hypothetical stratigraphic profiles to infer ecological and climate change through time, while students in advanced organic chemistry techniques courses will examine potential adulteration of olive oil samples, demonstrating real-world application of this technique. Acquisition of this instrumentation will also facilitate collaboration with nearby institutions such as UNC-Chapel Hill, East Carolina University, North Carolina State University, and Western Carolina University.

Specifically, this award provides for the acquisition of a gas chromatograph (GC), GC combustion interface, and flow controller to be interfaced with an existing Thermo Scientific DELTA V Plus mass spectrometer by researchers spanning four academic departments at the University of North Carolina Wilmington (UNCW). These upgrades will allow for the carbon, nitrogen, and hydrogen isotopic analyses of a wide variety of individual chemical compounds. The requested instrument will expand the capabilities of the UNCW stable isotope laboratory (SIL) and researchers within this region, given there is currently no instrument of this kind accessible to researchers in the state. The UNCW SIL is a core research and training facility located in at CMS and is currently used by more than 30 students, postdocs, and faculty from a wide variety of disciplines including anthropology, biology, chemistry, ecology, geography, geology, and marine science. The requested instrumentation will expand the analytical capabilities of the SIL and facilitate novel approaches to the active and future research topics of the researchers' intra- and inter-institutional collaborators, and their students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided funding to the University of North Carolina Wilmington (UNCW) to purchase a gas chromatograph (GC), GC combustion interface, and flow controller.  The GC was interfaced with an existing Thermo Scientific DELTA V Plus mass spectrometer at UNCW and will allow for the carbon, nitrogen, and hydrogen isotopic analyses of a wide variety of individual chemical compounds.  The instrument signficantly expanded research capabilities at UNCW and multiple other universities in the region given there was no instrument of this kind accessible to researchers in the area.

Over the three-year period of the project this instrumentaiton was used by investigators from five different universities and numerous academic disciplines to (1) reconstruct hydrologic changes in the southeastern United States and circum-Caribbean region on centennial to millenal timescales via hydrogen isotope analyses of terrestrially-derived lipids preserved in lake sediments; (2) source ethanol pollution in rainwater to biofuels used in internal combustion engines via carbon isotope analysis of this ethanol in natural rainwater; (3) reconstruct environmental change on the Portugeuse coast related to changes in North Atlantic atmospheric behaivor on centennial to millenial timescales; (4) reconstruct dietary patterns of ancient populations via carbon isotope analysis of fatty acids in pottery residues; and (5) reconstruct centennial-scale ecological changes in marsh systems due to changes in relative sea levels in the Pacific Northwest via carbon isotope analysis of plant-derived lipids.  This work has resulted in the publication of two peer-reviewed journal articles with three more in the review or preparation stage, six presentations at scientific conferences, and three graduate and one undergraduate theses.

The studies that are utilizing this newly acquired instrumentation and are have the potential to improve public knowledge of climate change, human history, and atmospheric pollution. Ultimately, when added to the ever growing body of existing literature on these subjects, these advances have the potential to shape human behavior via education and policy development, and thereby improve environmental and social conditions.

The broader impacts of this award include the training of three undergraduate students, five graduate students, two postdoctoral researchers, and one technician in the hands-on use and applications of this cutting-edge instrumentation. Additionally, ~60 graduate and undergraduate students were introduced to the instrumentation and its capabilities during lab tours.  Approximately 40 high school students were introduced to the instrumentation while conducting hands-on research projects as part of the UNCW MarineQuest Oceans-17 summer programs in 2016 and 2017.  Exposure to this cutting-edge technology at this early stage has proven powerful as numerous Oceans-17 students ultimately pursue scientific degrees at UNCW or other universities because of the curiosity sparked during these experiences. Acquisition of this instrumentation has also led to the development of numerous new inter-disciplinary collaborations and project concepts between faculty in multiple departments at UNCW and collaborators from the University of Tennesse, East Carolina University, the University of South Carolina, Western Carolina University, Berry College, and the University of Georgia.
